Dwellings (owner-occupied residence, other real estate) - Consumer durables (vehicles, etc.) - Valuables - Intellectual property ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} [**Financial assets**]{.red style="font-size:1.7rem"} - Currency and deposits - Net equity in own unincorporated business - Mututal funds and investment funds - (Private) Pensions funds - Bonds and other debt securities - Shares and other equity - Life insurance funds -Other financial assets ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} [**Liabilities**]{.red style="font-size:1.7rem"} - Owner-occupied residence loans - Consumer durable loans (e.g. for vehicles) - Other investment loans (collateralized) - Other loans (e.g. education loans) ::: ::: ::: ::: {.absolute top="70%" left="60%" .textbox .fragment .fade-up} No human, social and cultural capital; No public social security pensions (marketable vs. augmented wealth) ::: ::: {.aside} Source: @oecd:2013 ::: ## HFCS sampling and underreporting ::: {.incremental style="font-size:1.8rem"} - Target population in Austria: [3.9 million households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Gross sample in HFCS 2017: [6,280 households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Realized interviews: [3,072 households]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Response rate in HFCS 2017: [approx. 50%]{.hl .hl-dred .secfont} - Residual: [refused interviews]{.marker-hl}, invalid addresses, households not available, etc. ::: ::: {.absolute bottom="5%" left="10%" width="800px" .textbox .fragment .fade-up style="font-size:1.7rem;padding:0.5rem 1rem;" .altlist} - Response refusal correlates with wealth and is highest at the top [@vermeulen:2016] - Wealthy households own a greater number of assets and miss some components more easily [@kennickell:1999] ::: ## Upstream strategy against underreporting: Oversampling {.smaller} - Undercoverage and Underreporting - Oversampling is crucial for wealth surveys - Oversampling in HFCS 2017: :belgium: :cyprus: :de: :estonia: :es: :finland: :fr: :greece: :croatia: :hungary: :ireland: :latvia: :lithuania: :luxembourg: :poland: :portugal: :slovakia: - No oversampling: :austria: :it: :malta: :netherlands: :slovenia: - How does oversampling work? - External personal wealth data (:fr: :es:) - List of streets with high-income people (:de: :slovakia:) - Income tax data (:luxembourg: 20% of the sample from top 10% earners) - Regions with higher average income (:poland:) ## Downstream strategy against underreporting: Pareto estimation {.smaller} - Pareto-Distribution is a sensible approximation to the distribution of large wealth - Two parameters: - Threshold for "large" wealth $m$ - Pareto-Index $\alpha$ $$P_i(x_i) = Pr(X_i \leqslant x_i) = 1 - \left(\frac{m_i}{x_i}\right)^{\alpha_i}$$ $$\forall ~\text{implicates} ~i = 1...5 \wedge x_i \geqslant m_i$$ ::: {.fragment .fade-in} [A smaller $\alpha$ means greater inequality.
